awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Zeiss 880 Multiphoton and AiryScan Microscope System as a Shared Instrument for the Washington University Research Community
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to support the acquisition of a multiphoton confocal microscope to address the research needs of a large, diverse group of researchers in multiple departments at Washington University and in the St. Louis area. The new system will be housed in the Biology Department Imaging Core and will be readily accessible to university and regional users. The new imaging capabilities of this instrument will enable cutting edge multidisciplinary research and promote a well-prepared, diverse STEM workforce including students in underrepresented groups. The microscope will enhance the hands-on training of undergraduates through existing courses, in addition to the many Independent Study undergraduates that already use the Core. Furthermore, the instrument will enable the development of new teaching modules for other undergraduate biology classes where the need to procure data for many students in a short time frame precludes the use of existing instruments. This instrument will also have a large impact on underrepresented students involved in the Science Career Explorations programs, YMCA campus Y program for inner-city school children, and ENDURE program for underrepresented students entering neuroscience graduate school.

The field of live cell imaging has recently enabled researchers to resolve physiological and molecular events in cells deep within tissues with micron- and millisecond-resolution. The new multiphoton system will provide deep, fast and super-resolution imaging technology for the first time to users in the departments of Biology, Physics, and Engineering at Washington University and from area institutions. Initial research uses for the new system will include work on cortical microtubules in plant cells; analysis of biosensors in root cells and pollen dynamics.  Other researchers working with animal systems will study neuronal cell populations, tendon fascicles, and a range of other topics. Results from these studies will be published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, presented at scientific meetings, and used in both training and outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As Covid restrictions have begun to loosen since July of 2021, the Washington University Imaging Facility is experiencing an unprecedented increase in use of our instruments, most notably for use of the Multi photon-Single photon suite that was acquired with funds from NSF MRI award number 1828481.  Since May of 2021, usage of these two instruments has totaled over 45 hours per week, comprising 90% of the total usage of all instruments in the facility.  As a further indicator of the rising interest and use of these instruments, of the 27 new users that have been trained since the last report in October 2020, 25 have trained just since May.  In fact, 15 of these users have trained in just the past 6 weeks. Users come from a wide range of disciplines, including the Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Electrical, Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering departments on the undergraduate campus, and the Developmental Biology Department in the School of Medicine. These users include faculty, staff scientists, post-doctoral students, graduate students, technicians, and undergraduates pursuing independent study with faculty mentors.  These instruments have proven to be particularly popular due to both the quality of the images acquired and the ease of use of both the hardware and software.

 

In past years, the instruments have also been used for hands-on classroom instruction in several undergraduate classes as well as guided tours for students and secondary school groups.   Unfortunately, use of the instruments for classroom activities has been on hold throughout the fall semester as the University has been slowly returning to in-person instruction. Nonetheless, tours have been provided for several faculty candidates since the beginning of 2021 and were very well received by those candidates, 3 of which have accepted positions in our department and are anticipated to use the instruments after their arrival in the spring and fall of 2022. It is hoped that if the Covid positive levels remain low we will be able to return to in-person class use of the instruments as early as the upcoming 2022 spring semester.

Modified by: Ram Dixit
